What slender Youth, upon a rosy Bed</br>Perfum'd with liquid Odours, shall caress</br>Thee, Pyrrha, in some cool Retreat?</br>For whom bind'st thou thy golden Hair,
Neat in thy Cleanliness? — Alas!  how oft</br>Thy Faith and changeful Gods will he deplore:</br>Thy Ocean, swelling with dark Winds,</br>Shall fright his unaccustom'd Soul:
He, who too cred'lously enjoys thy Calm,</br>Who always thinks thee vacant, always lovely;</br>Vain Fool, a Stranger to the Gale</br>Fallacious! — Miserable they
To whom, untry'd, you shine! — But as for me,</br>The votive Tablet shews, that I have hung</br>My dripping Garments to the God,</br>Who rules the hoary Main.</br>
